FacilityName: Morehead Utility Plant Board Water Treatment Plant

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The stationary source and regulated substances handled:

    The Morehead Utility Plant Board (MUPB) is located in the City of Morehead, Kentucky.  MUPB is responsible for the water treatment plant operation that serves 3500 water customers and was constructed in 1968.  The water supplied by the Water Treatment Plant is purified in accordance with rules and regulations of the Kentucky Division of Water.  The water treatment plant uses and ACTLIFO® water clarification process with pre- and post- chlorination.  The water quality is closely monitored at the water treatment plant with the latest in monitoring technology and control equipment.



    The water treatment plant uses chlorine gas to disinfect the raw water prior to delivery to the community.  The maximum quantity of chlorine in storage is 6,000 pounds contained in three one-ton cylinders.  MUPB has implemented written programs and has conducted periodic training and program inspections to insure that the preventive measure needed to safely manage and use chlorine are practiced.



Five Year Accident History:

    Since its startup in 1968, the water treatment plant has not had any accidents resulting in death, injury, or significant property damage on site, or any offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.  MUPB believes that our chemical accident preparedness and prevention programs with regard to chlorine have been significant contributor to our safety record to date.



Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the water plant:

    The top priority of water delivery by MUPB is worker and community safety and environmental stewardship.  To that end, MUPB continues to work closely with local and state agencies to implement programs as required by federal, state, and local regulations.



General accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps:

    MUPB is committed to operating the chlorine system in a saf

e manner.  Plant personnel are given periodic training on safety information (including information pertaining to the hazards of the regulated substances used or produced by the water treatment process), the technology of the process, and the equipment in the process.  In addition, MUPB has developed and implemented written operating procedures to provide clear instructions for safe use and operation of the chlorine process equipment, conducts periodic maintenance of process components, and safely manages change to the covered process or equipment through the use of management of change procedures.



Planned changes to improve safety:

    The water treatment plant continues to address safe practices related to the storage and use of chlorine through personnel training, employee participation, and employee feedback.



Emergency Response Program:

    The water treatment plant has written emergency response plan that includes actions required for a chlorine release, is part of the Rowan County LEPC, and routinely conducts safety drills with the local fire department and emergency agencies from Morehead, KY.  Upon notification of a release of chlorine gas by MUPB, local officials will implement the appropriate protective actions identified in the city emergency response plan and in the plant emergency operation plan (EOP).  Based on the event, these actions may include evacuation, shelter in place, or no action.  Evacuation of threatened areas will be conducted in conformance with the EOP.  The response time to an incident at this facility by police, fire, and ambulance should not be over 10 minutes.  An evacuation radius of 2.2 miles was determined through the use of the EPA's RMP* Comp software.  MUPB understands that the local police department can use a Code Red Phone System override to alert the population in the affected area.  Saint Claire Regional Medical Center has the capability of providing medical services for chlorine exposure, including removing contaminants
by flushing eyes and washing the contaminated skin area and treating victims that may have inhaled the chemical.
